content:
Hyndburn Borough Council paid £1.1 million to 17 suppliers that were in active breach of Companies House requirements — including companies with no active directors, meaning they may have been unable to legally authorise contracts or sign agreements on behalf of the company.

Under the Companies Act 2006 (sections 154-156), every private company must have at least one director who is a natural person. A company with no active directors cannot legally operate, make decisions, or enter into contracts. Yet Hyndburn continued paying them with public money.

The Worst Cases

Supplier Paid During Breach Issue
B3P Services Ltd£420,200No active directors
JDS Trucks Ltd£287,300No active directors AND no PSC
Homewise Society Ltd£158,600No active directors AND no PSC

What Does "No Active Directors" Actually Mean?

When a company has no active directors registered at Companies House, it means:

  • No one can legally sign contracts — any agreement the council entered into may be unenforceable
  • No one is legally responsible — if something goes wrong, there is no director to hold accountable
  • The company may be fraudulent — shell companies and dormant entities sometimes have no directors
  • Annual accounts may not be filed — meaning the company's financial health is unknown

B3P Services Ltd: £420,200 — The Biggest Concern

B3P Services Ltd received over £420,000 from Hyndburn while having no active directors registered at Companies House. This is the single largest payment to a non-compliant supplier across all three East Lancashire councils we analysed. Who authorised these contracts? Who verified the company was capable of delivering?

JDS Trucks Ltd: £287,300 — No Directors AND No PSC

JDS Trucks Ltd had neither active directors nor a person with significant control (PSC) registered. The PSC register was introduced to prevent money laundering and tax evasion. A company with no PSC is essentially invisible to regulatory oversight — yet it received nearly £290,000 of public money.

How This Compares

Across the three East Lancashire councils:

  • Hyndburn: £1.1 million to 17 suppliers — worst compliance record
  • Burnley: £223,900 to breaching suppliers
  • Pendle: £37,800 to 4 suppliers — best compliance record

Hyndburn's exposure is nearly five times that of Burnley and 29 times that of Pendle. This is not a rounding error — it suggests a systemic failure in supplier due diligence.

What Should Happen

The council should immediately:

  1. Review all 17 suppliers and verify their current Companies House status
  2. Check whether contracts signed by companies with no directors are legally valid
  3. Implement automated Companies House checks before any payment is processed
  4. Publish the results of their review

Companies House data accessed via the official API. Payment data from Hyndburn Borough Council transparency publications. Legal references: Companies Act 2006, ss.154-156 (requirement for directors), s.790M (PSC register).
